title: Tutorchain.io - Expert identity
description: 専門家を見つけたり、自分の専門知識を収益化するためには、集中的な審査サービスが必要となり、選択肢が制限され、アクセスもコントロールされます。

f6_assessments.q0: This is a nice idea, however is is not clear how it fits this challenge. It is an app to line up tutors with learners. The proposers have submitted a basically the same idea into 5 other challenges. In the metadata challenge it seemed to fit reasonably well but they have not stated how it fits with this challenge. This specific submission is basically a perfect cut and paste as that submitted to the developer ecosystem challenge and the  Catalyst value onboarding. The only difference is it is 10k rather than 5k or 15k the cost (likely adjusted to the total money available in the challenges).
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer likely have the experience to set up the platform generally and it will likely be implemented as described, though the fact they have sent it into different challenges with difference costs makes me wonder about what the budget should really be?
f6_assessments.q2: Delivery of the platform is easy to audit, however what's really important for this use case is how it will impact Atala PRISM DID Mass-Scale Adoption. They have not covered how it is relevant that how can it be a success for the challenge?

f6_assessments.q0:
The challenge is asking for a way to drive mass-scale adoption of DID usage as an easy-to-use onramp to the Cardano ecosystem.
The problem statement should more closely align with the challenge however the solution is clear and reasonable.
The goal of a DID linked reputation system for tutors/students aligns with the challenge objective.
The proposal is might be able to scale to drawing in millions of DID users. The proposal's target market info should include the number of online tutors and students in the market. The competitive advantages over similar existing services are clearly stated. The go-to-market plan is a little weak as it simply relies on existing contacts and networking from there.
The funding request is actually for testing two approaches to preventing sybil attacks, Atala Prism DIDs vs simple social network analysis. Ultimately, if the simple social network analysis is deemed sufficient then the challenge objective would not be met.
Based upon my experience, I disagree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has provided sufficient evidence of relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal.
The team has been sufficiently identified in terms of skills and number required to implement the proposal.
The budget is for testing purposes that may not achieve the campaign goals and is not broken down into identifiable items. 
I recommend requesting funds to integrate DID with your product instead of "This means that our network must be independently sybil-resistant (zoom recordings give us good access to data, but simple social network analysis might be enough), or we must partner with a complete digital identity solution like Atala prism. We are requesting $10k in funds to test both approaches to digital identity." 
The timetable does not mention the work being funded.
The plan does not describe the resources necessary to implement the proposal.
The proposal does not identify risks and challenges to a successful implementation.
Based upon my experience, I neither agree nor disagree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal does not provide a roadmap with auditable milestones and a defined timeline that relates to the testing work being funded.
The proposal should include projected metrics that correspond to the challenge objective such as the number of DID users projected to be onboarded at specific time intervals and the recruitment cost per DID user. 
The proposal should detail specifically how progress will be reported back to the Catalyst community at regular intervals.
Based upon my experience, I disagree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea is sound, and there is a need for this, but I question whether it should be part of a digital identity especially when a portion of this proposal has centralized assets involved. Someone's reviews of a person probably should not be considered identity.
However, there is value in the services they provide, or will provide. This could be a possible component of existing educational efforts, and possibly the commercial aspect and lack of open source sharing is what I have some issue with. Also, it maybe worth mentioning there is not a tie in with Atala PRISM while there would seem to be a use and need for one. It would seem to me that Atala should provide the decentralized assets for this proposal while it focused on the centralized ones: and those centralized assets and the Tutorchain.io app then expands Atala. I could be wrong and not understanding how Tutorchain.io relates to Atala, however.
f6_assessments.q1: It would seem to develop the centralized and Plutus aspects of the smart contracts involving tutors and their reviews seems like a series of tasks well within the experience of the Tutorchain.io team. Perhaps their more difficult sets of tasks are related to business process, and marketing...bringing on clients. I think this proposal is within reality to succeed, but just perhaps in the wrong category.
f6_assessments.q2:
Their 3, 6, and 12 month milestones seem sufficient for this project. In one year and after $10K: results produced can be of good value. Their information provided seems to present information about their tasks and plans to say yes indeed that they could succeed and present some value to Cardano at the fruition of the project. I just question how that value relates to Atala, but could be wrong in that it should be. If, however, this proposal is just to provide value to digital identity: this it can probably do.

The proposers do explain their multiple submissions for Tutorchain.io, and that this submission is for the digital identity aspect. I am concerned though that this borders on just being a marketing attempt. The proposers mention how Cardano is their top choice. It would seem if this proposal is good-to-go that their blockchain choice, and perhaps an integration with Atala, would be more solid in this proposal and that leads me to question if this is indeed a proposal or marketing for Tutorchain.io (the app name within the proposal name could also be telling here).

f6_assessments.q0: This is a use case in which it would bring a large amount of user if it was adopted. Reputation for expertise and knowledge without having to rely on a central authority is very attractive.
f6_assessments.q1: I believe they will have the required experience to effectively target a certain market as they beging this process considering their experience and current professions. It addresses the problems it wishes to solve so they know where they need to end up and have laid a plan out to get there.
f6_assessments.q2: They do lay out measurable success markers as far as the creation of the project. For how well it is adopted, they do not have measures for that but that may be figured out once the product is working and out in the market.

solution: スマートコントラクトを使用して、金銭的な交換に関連付けられた検証可能な顧客レビューを保存します。専門家は自分がコントロールする評判を構築する。
experience: 創業者は、ソフトウェアエンジニア（暗号化スタートアップの経験あり）と物理学教授で、家庭教師市場を獲得するためのスキルとコネクションを持っています。
